bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê yâhkih mâh-mêscihtâsôw wîhtikôw . Once upon a time, long ago, a Windigo carried on his work of extermination.
tapasîwak êsah mitâtaht oskinîkiwak . Ten youths took flight.

âyîtaw ê-ohkwâkanit awa wîhtikôw , mihcêt âtah mîkiwâhpah êh-ihtakohkih , êsa mâna êh-mâh-mêscihtât . That Windigo, with a face on either side of his head, no matter how many tents there were, always killed off all the people.

mitâtaht êsa êy-ihtasicik ôki oskinîkiwak ,
tapasîtân ! itwêwak êsa ; Then those youths, who were ten, said, “Let us flee!
kiyânaw pikoh kik-êskwahikonaw , itwêwak êsah . We alone shall not be killed,” they said.
mîkiwâhp wâhyaw wacîhk ntawih-osîhtâwak . far off on a mountain they went to build their tipi.
nâtêwak osîmisiwâwa . they fetched their little brother.
êkotê nikwatis owîkiwak . They had their tent off there alone.

êkotê kîtahtawê êh-wa-wîkicik , kîtahtawê nâpêsis mâna êh-kanawâpokêt , kîtahtawê êsah êh-pônahk , kâ-kisisihk . Then, at one time, as they continued to dwell off there, and the little boy always stayed to keep the house, then presently, as he was feeding the fire, he ran a splinter into himself.
miscikos wîhkwacipitam . He pulled out the sliver of wood.

ômah miscikos ositihk kâ-kisisihk iskwâhtêmihk êh-wêpinahk , kâ-pêh-pîhtokêtâcimoyit iskwêsisah . When he threw out of the door that sliver of wood which he had run into his foot, there came crawling in a little girl.

otinêw êsah ,
misawâc namoya nika-kîh-ohpikihâw , êh-itêyihtahk êsa . He lifted her up, thinking, “It is no use, I should not be able to bring her up.”
êkwah kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit , âsay mîna ê-kîh-wayawîwêpinât , âsay mîna kîhtwâm wayawîwêpinêw . When she came into the tent, after he had twice thrown her out, again he threw her out.

êkwah kîhtwâm êh-pê-pîhtokêyit ,
nistêsê ! k-êtikot êsah . Then, when again she came in, she called to him, “Big brother!”

ah , mahti mînah ! ahpôh êtokê kit-ôskinîkiskwêww , kîhtwâm wayawîwêpinakih ! itêyihtam êsah . “Ho, I had better do it again! I should not be surprised if she were to turn into a young woman, if I threw her out again!” he thought.

êkwah ômisih itwêw :
kita-wîh-oskinîkiskwêwiw , ahpôh êtokê êh-wîcihikowisiyân ! itwêw êsah . Then he spoke thus: “Let her be a young woman, since it seems that I am being aided by the Powers!” he said.

êkwah kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit oskinîkiskwêwa ,
ay-apih , nimisê ! itwêw êsa awa nâpêsis . Then, when there entered a young woman, “Be seated, my big sister!” said the boy.
pihkahtêwâhtik isiyîhkâtêw êsah ôhi oskinîkiskwêwah . “Burnt-Stick” it seems that he called the young woman.
mînah êh-mihcêtiyit ostêsah , miywêyihtam kita-pamihikocik ôhi oskinîkiskwêwah . and he was glad that all his elder brothers would have this young woman to do their household work for them.
êkotah êsah mâka mîna wîkihkêmôw wîsahkêcâhk ôhih oskinîkiwah ; And now it appears that in his usual way Wisahketchahk was staying with these young men;
êwako ohci , k-ôh-kiskêyihtamiyit kit-êsih-tapasiyit ôhih wîhtikôwa . it was because they knew in which direction that Windigo would take flight.
ayîsk kih-mahpinêw wîsahkêcâhk ; êwak ôhci kâ-wîsâmât ôhi oskinîkiwah . For Wisahketchahk was badly frightened; that was why he had asked hospitality of these young men.
mâcikah , nisîmis ! itwêw êsah . “You will see, little brother!” he must have said.
nîkân êsah mâna pîhtokêw awa wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was always the first to come into the tipi.

tânisi kah-itêyihtên , itwêw awa nâpêsis ,
oskinîkiskwêw kit-âyâwâyahk ? itwêw êsah . “What would you think,” asked the boy, “of our having a young woman?”

êkwah wiya wîsahkêcâhk ,
kik-ôsîminânaw ! itwêw ; And Wisahketchahk, for his part, said, “We shall have her as our younger sister!”
kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-osîmiw ayisk êsah wîsahkêcâhk . for it seems that Wisahketchahk had every manner of creature for his younger brother and sister.

kîtahtawê êkwah mistahi kâ-kâyawisiyiwa ôhi osîmiwâwa , êh-kaskikwâtikocik , mînah êh-paminawasoyit . Then this younger sister of theirs was very diligent, sewing for them, and doing their household work.
mitoni êsah kwayask pamihikwak , êkwah mistahi wîstawâw êsah êh-kitimâkêyimâcik . It seems that she kept them very well, so that they, in turn, became very fond of her.

êkwah êh-mâh-mâcîcik , cêmâk wîpac êsah mâna êh-atih-kîsihtâyit pahkêkinwah , êkwah mâna otayôwinisiwâwa êw-osîhtâyit , mitoni kwayask êsah êh-pamihikocik . When they did their hunting, without delay, it seems, she always tanned the hides and made clothes for them, taking in every way excellent care of them.

kîtahtawêh ômisih itwêw êsah wîsahkêcâhk :
âh , âsay kiskêyihtam ôtah êh-ayâyahk âyîtaw k-ôhkwâkanit wîhtikôw , itwêw êsah ; Presently Wisahketchahk spoke as follows “Oh, by this time the Windigo with a face on either side of his head knows that we are here,” he said;

êkwah mîna kêkway pêhtamanih , êkâya wîhkâc nâkatôhkêh , nêkohtêyani , itêw êsah ôhi oskinîkiskwêwah , pîhkahtêwâhtik k-êsiyihkâsoyit ; “And then, if you hear anything, never listen to it, when you are gathering wood,” he must have told the young woman who was called Burnt-Stick;

êkwah êsa ,
êkâya wîhkâc , wâpahtamanih kêkway , otin , îtêy êsah ,
otinah . and “Never, when you see anything, take it up,” he told her; Never take it up.

seg.gloss: Then we shall be off visiting again.

seg.q: kêkway mîna pêhtamanih , êkâ apiyâhkoh , mistahi manitôww k-âyîtawihkwâkanêt wîhtikôw .
seg.gloss: If then again you hear anything, when we are not at home, great manitou power has that two-faced Windigo.

p.seg: êkosi niya wiya wîsahkêcâhk nikostâw , itwêw êsah wîsahkêcâhk ; So great that even I, Wisahketchahk, fear him,” Wisahketchahk must have said;
êkwah mîna tâpiskôc niyânân kik-êtihtawinân , itwêw êsah ; “Then, again, you will hear exactly, as it will seem, the sound of our voices,” he said;

seg.gloss: “Really, for four nights we shall be off visiting.
And it will be very cold weather.
Then you will hear our voices;

p.seg: êkâ yôhtênamôhkan , itêw êsah ôhih oskinîkiskwêwah . do not open the door,” he must have told the young woman.

tâpwê ê-kîh-kakêskimiht awa oskinîkiskwêw , êkwah mâci-nikohtêw , mayaw kahkiyaw ê-sipwêhtêyit ôhi ostêsah . Accordingly, when the young woman had been instructed, she started to gather firewood, as soon as all her brothers had gone away.
êkwah kahkiyaw mîna kîsâc nâh-nâtwaham ; And she split all the wood, so that it should be quite ready for use;
mîn êsah kîsâc kahkiyaw pîhtokatâw ; and she brought it all indoors ready for use;
êkwah êsah mîna kotak kîskatahwêw ê-misikitiyit mîtosah . and she cut a big poplar tree besides.
êkwah sôhkih mitonih kipaham wîkiwâw . Then she closed up their tipi solidly.
mistah êsah kisinâw . It was very cold weather.

êkwah kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-itwêwiht :
nisîmis , nitakosininân ! kâ-matwêh-itwêwiht êsah . Presently she heard someone call, “Little sister, here we are!” seemed to be spoken for her to hear.
namoya êsah wih-waskawîw . she did not stir from the spot.
piysk wâsakâm êkotah wîkihk mâtwêh-nipahaciyiwa . At last all round the lodge there was the sound of them dying of cold.
êh-âtah-wayawît , namwâc ahpôh awiyah kita-mâtahât . when she went outside, she found not even a footprint.
mâmaskâtam . She wondered.
tâpw êcik ânih ! itêyihtam awa oskinîkiskwêw . “So it really is thus!” thought the young woman.
nêo-tipiskâw êh-kîh-ispayik , takohtêwak ôki oskinîkiwak . When four nights had passed, the young men arrived.

êkwah mâna kah-kapê-kîsik êh-nikohtêt piko awa oskinîkiskwêw , nama wîhkâc kêkway otinam , âtah nanâtohk kêkway wiyâpahtahkih . Then, when the young woman always gathered wood all day, she never picked up anything, although she saw all manner of things.
kîtahtawê êsa mistahih êh-miyosiyit mêkwanah wâpamêw êsah . But then at one time she saw a most beautiful feather.

êkwah otinêw ,
mêtokêtah êkâ kika-wayêsihitih ! k-êtikot , kayahtê ôtah êy-ohci-pasikôyit ôhi wîhtikôwa âyîtaw k-ôhkwâkaniyit . She picked it up, when, “Of course I could not get the better of you!” said the two-faced Windigo, suddenly rising from the feather.

ômisih êsah itwêw awa wîhtikôw :
tâpwê niwîh-miyo-mîcison , pihkahtêwâhtik ê-wîh-mowak ! Thus spoke the Windigo: “Truly, I shall have good eating, when I eat Burnt-Stick!

seg.gloss: Now, Burnt-Stick, first I shall take you home with me; I shall make you fat.”

p.seg: êkosi awa wîhtikôw nayômêw êsa ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa . With that the Windigo took the young woman on his back and carried her.
kîwêhtahêw , mistahi êsa êh-kakwâtakihât nôtokêsiwa êh-ayâwât , He took her home with him, to where he had an old woman whom he led a dreadful life;

tahto-kîsikâw êh-kwayâci-pakahtamâkot , êh-kwayâci-kîsisamâkot , tahto-kîsikâw êsah mâna nîso ayîsiyiniwah ohcih êh-mowât , êkwah mâna ayîsiyiniw otakisiyah , têkohtêcih , pita nîkân êyakonih êsah mâna êh-mîcit . every day this old woman had his stew ready for him, cooking it done before he got home, for every day he ate two men, his habit being, as soon as he got home, first to eat their entrails.

êkwah ,
nôhko , itwêw êsah ; So now, “Grandmother,” he said;

seg.gloss: “have you boiled the entrails ready for me to eat?

seg.q: mistahi êkwah miyosiw oskinîkiskwêw kâ-pêsiwak , ta-mowak .
seg.gloss: Now very pretty is the young woman I have brought home to eat.

p.seg: âhkamêyimoh êh-kakwê-wiyinowat , itwêw êsah . Do not spare your pains to fatten her,” he said.

tâpwêh ,
êhag , itwêw êsah awah nôtokêsiw . Then, “Very well,” said the old woman.
mistahi miywêyimêw ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa awa nôtokêsiw , pihkahtêwâhtik k-êsiyîhkâsoyit . The old woman became very fond of the maid, Burnt-Stick.

êkwah êsah ,
nôsisê , tâpwê mistah iyâkwâma ta-nipahitân nipakwâtên , itwêw êsa ; Then, it seems, “Grandchild, surely I hate the very thought of killing you,” she said;

seg.gloss: “Do try to deceive him;

p.seg: niya nipahin , itwêw êsa awa nôtokêw ; do you, instead, kill me,” the old woman said;
êkwah êkosi kika-pakâsimin , itwêw êsa awa nôtokêw . “And then you will set me to boil,” said the old woman.
tâpwê awa oskinîkiskwêw miywêyihtam êy-itikot ôhi nôtokêsiwa . Truly, the maid was pleased at what the old woman told her.
tânisi mâka kê-tôtamân ta-nipahitân ? itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiskwêw . “But how must I do to kill you?” asked the young woman.
ômisi , itwêw awa nôtokêw ; Thus spoke the old woman: If quoting is right, more like: “Like this,” said the old woman.

seg.gloss: “You will take an ax;

p.seg: nistikwânihk ka-pakamahân , itwêw awa nôtokêw ; you will strike a blow on my head,” said the old woman; ? or maybe relational ka-pakamahwân

seg.q: ôtêh êkâ êh-pîsimôwik nêô osêtinâwa , ôm ôtah nistam osêhcâw kik-âmaciwân .
seg.gloss: “Yonder, in the direction where there is no sun, are four hills, the first and nearest of which you will climb.

seg.q: êkotah ohci mînah kotak spatinâw ka-têpâpahtên .
seg.gloss: From there you will see the second hill.

seg.q: nêô ispatinâwa miyâskamani , êkotê kakwê-takwâmôhkan pîwâpisko-wâskahikan .
seg.gloss: When you have crossed four hills, there try to reach in your flight an iron house.
The one who dwells there will overcome him.

p.seg: kîspin êkotê takwâmoyani , êkosi kika-pimâtisin , itik êsah ; If you manage to get there in your flight, then you will live,” she told her;

seg.q:
takwâmoyani êkotê , ômisi itwêhkan :
nistêsê , niwîh-nipahik âyîtawihkwâkan wîhtikôw ! kik-êtwân .
seg.gloss: “When you reach the place in your flight, speak thus: “Big brother, the both-side-faced Windigo wants to kill me!' you will say.
Then they will open the door for you.”

p.seg: tâpwê êh-kih-kakêskimikot awa pîhkahtêwâhtik ôhi nôtokêsiwah , pakamahwêw ostikwâniyihk . Accordingly, even as the old woman had directed Burnt-Stick, she struck her on the head.
êkwah êkos îsi wiyanihêw , ê-kih-nipahât . Then she skinned her and cut her up, whom she had slain.
pakâsimêw . She put her in the kettle to boil.
êh-kih-kîsiswât , êkos îsi sôhkih tapasîw . When she had cooked her done, she ran away as fast as she could.
pimipahtâw mitoni sôhkih . She ran with all her might.

kîtahtawâ ispatinâw ntawâpahtahk , êh-atih-kapê-tipisk êh-pimipahtât . Presently she saw a hill, and all night long she ran. LB: Inclusion of other words between prefixed particle and verb is very uncommon; more common is the start, as here, toward such inclusion, which is then annulled by forming the verb all over again.
âsay mîna kotak ispatinâw wâpahtam ; Then she saw another hill;
âsay mîna êwakoh miyâskam . she crossed it, too.
mîna kotak ispatinâw wâpahtam ; êwako mîna miyâskam . She saw another hill; this, too, she crossed.
kotak spatinâw êh-âmaciwêt , âsay êkwah kâ-matwê-têpwâtikot ôhi wîhtikôwa . When she climbed the next hill, already she heard the Windigo shouting to her.
namoya misawâc kitah-pîhcâw askiy kit-êtâmoyan ! kâ-matwê-isi-têpwâtikot . “It is no use! The earth will not be large enough to give you refuge!” he shouted to her.
mistahi êsa kisiwâsiw awa wîhtikôw , ôhkomah êh-mowât . It appears that the Windigo was very angry at having eaten his grandmother.
kotak êw-osêhcâyik êh-âmaciwêt , ôtah nîhcâyihk kîh-astêyiw pîwâpisko-wâskahikan . as she climbed the rise, there down below was the iron house.
nâwiy êh-itâpit , kîh-pêtisâpamêw êsah wîhtikôwa ; When she looked behind her, already she saw the Windigo coming;
sôhkih êsah êkwah tâpwê tâpasîw . then really she fled with all her might.
êh-otihtahk , wani-kiskisiw tânisi kâ-kîh-isi-kâkêskimikot ôhi nôtokêsiwa ka-kîh-nipahât . When she reached it, she forgot the instruction she had been given by the old woman whom she had killed.

seg.gloss: “Open the door for me!

p.seg: âyîtawiskîsik niwîh-nipahik , nistêsê ! itwêw êsah . Both-Side-Eyes wants to kill me, big brother!” she cried.

pikw îsi âtah êh-itwêt , mwêhcih êkwah ê-wîh-pê-sakinikot , kâ-kiskisôpayit anihi nôtokêsiwa kâ-kîh-si-kâkêskimikot . Although she called in all manner of ways, he was even about to seize her, when she remembered what the old woman had told her.

nistêsê , itwêw êsah mîna kîhtwâm ,
tawinamawin ! itwêw êsah ; “Big brother,” she cried again, “open the door for me!” she cried;
âyîtawihkwâkan niwîh-nipahik ! itwêw êsah . “Both-Side-Face wants to kill me!” she cried.
yôhtêpayiyiw ôma pîwâpisko-waskahikan . The door of the iron house swung open.
pîhtokêw êsah . She went in.
wâpamêw êkotah pîhcâyihk êh-owîkiyit oskinîkiskwêwah mîn oskinîkiwah . She saw those who had their dwelling inside there, a young woman and a young man.

ômisi êsa itik ôhih oskinîkiskwêwah :
ncâhkos , ay-apih ! itik êsah . Then the young woman said to her, “sister-in-law, sit down!”
kîtahtawê wayawîtimihk ôtah kâ-matwê-takohtêyit ôhi wîhtikôwah . Soon with noise the Windigo arrived outside.
tawinamawin , pîwâpisko-wâskahikan k-ôwîkit ! itwêyiwah êsah . “Open for me, Iron-House-Dweller!” he cried.
êkosi êsah yôhtênam awa oskinîkiw , êh-atih-kîskikwêtahwât ôhih wîhtikôwa . Then the young man opened the door and chopped off the Windigo's head.
êkwah awa oskinîkiskwêw êkotah ay-ayâw . Then the young woman stayed there.
ayisk mistahi kitimâkêyimik ôhi oskinîkiskwêwah mîn ôhi nâpêwah . For that young woman and that man were very good to her.
kîtahtawê kâ-pîmoyohikot kêkway ohcih kitah-manitôwit . Then in time, they gave her something to keep in the bosom-fold of her garment, to give her manitou power.
mistahi êkwah mîn êyako manitôwiw êsah . she too had now manitou power.
êkwah osîhtâyiwa nâpêw-ayôwinisah , êkotôwa êkwah êh-posiskahk , mîna onâpêwin êh-osîhtâyit . Then they made men's clothes, which she put on, [no translation]
tâpwê papâmâcîw . Then really, she went about hunting.

kîtahtawê ômisi itik ôhi :
mistahi kistêsak kipîkiskâtikwak . Then at one time they said to her, “Your brothers miss you very much.
mistahi kakwâtakihtâwak , nawac kakwê-wâpamacik , itik ; They are suffering greatly; you ought to try to see them,” they told her;

seg.q: ih , tâpwê wiya ôtah namoya wâhyaw ispatinâw kik-ôtihtên .
seg.gloss: “Now, not far from here you will come to a hill.

seg.q: êkotah mîkiwâhp ka-wâpahtên , mitonih ê-misâk , êkotah ayîsiyiniwak ohcitaw êh-kakwâtikihât , êh-wacistwanihkêt , êkwah mâna ayîsiyiniwah êh-tâh-têhci-kwâskohtit ,
seg.gloss: There you will see a very large tipi. He who lives there is intent on tormenting people; he builds a nest from which he jumps on people.

p.seg: êkotah mitonih êh-sâkaskinêcik ayîsiyiniwak , nanâtohk êy-isi-kakwâtakihtâcik , pikw îtôwihk êh-ati-pah-pîkoskawât anah êkotah k-âyât mac-âyîsiyiniw , itik êsah ; That place is full of people who suffer from all kinds of injuries, since that evil person who lives there breaks different parts of their bodies as he comes down on them,” they told her;

seg.q: êwako piko êh-âyimahk , mâka pikoh oskinîkiskwêwa êkonih pikoh k-êtinât wiya ; nâpêwa namoya pisiskêyimêw .
seg.gloss: “This is the only difficulty, but, after all, he takes only young women; he pays no attention to men.

p.seg:
mayaw pimâpamiskih , ômisi kik-êtik :
mahtih sikitân , awîna wâhyaw kê-pahkihtiniyik , itik êsah ; “As soon as he sees you, he will say to you, “[no translation]” they told her;

seg.gloss: “That is what he will say to you.”

p.seg: êh-kîsi-kakêskimiht awa oskinîkiskwêw , wayawîw , êh-otinahk kit-si-nîmât . When the young woman had been instructed, she went out of the house, taking provision for the journey.
sipwêhtêw êsah . She set out.
êkwah kîtahtawê , mayaw êh-at-îspi-kîsikâyik , kâ-wâpahtahk . Presently, just as they day had reached noon, she saw the place.

ât êsah wâhyaw êh-wîmâhtêt , êsah wâpamik ôhih mac-âyîsiyiniwah , kâ-kapê-kîsik kâ-tâh-têhci-kwâskohtiyit , ohcitaw êsah mitoni mihcêt ê-kâkwâtakihât awah oskinîkiskwêwah . Although she walked far round to avoid it, she must have been seen by that evil man who all day jumped down on young women, taking pleasure in tormenting them.

kâ-pê-nakiskâkot , ômisi êsah itik :
mahtih sikitân , awîna wâhyaw kê-pahkihtiniyik , nîscâs ! When he had come and met her, he said to her, “[no translation]”
itâhkômik êsah . So it seemed he was her cousin.
mwêhci ê-wî-sikit , kâ-manipitamiyit ôma ostêsah kâ-kîh-osîhtâyit . [no translation]

seg.gloss: “‘My male cousin,’ I have been calling her; why it is Burnt-Stick!”

p.seg: êkos îsi kîmôc otinam mistik , misâskwatos ; saskawohtêw . Thereupon she secretly took up a stick of saskatoon wood; she used it as a cane.
êh-atih-kîwêh-sakiniskênikot , pîhtokahik . He led her home by the hand and took her into his tipi.
pôtih êsah misiwê kâ-wâpamât oskinîkiskwêwa pikw îtôwihk êh-nâ-nâtwâskikâsoyit . And there she saw nothing but young women whose bodies were broken in every way from having been jumped on.

ômisi itwêwak ôkih oskinîkiskwêwak :
m ânih kiyânaw mîna êkosi êh-kîh-isi-miyosiyahk , awa oskinîkiskwêw k-êsi-miyosit ! itwêwak ôki kâ-mâ-mâskisicik . These young women said, “Only to think that we, too, were as beautiful as this young woman!” Thus spoke those crippled ones.

hâw , êstâyit êsah têhtapiwin , kiyîhcêkosiyit mistikwa ôtah êh-cimasoyit , otinam ômah kâ-kîh-manahot ômah mistik . Then, when he had placed a seat, and had climbed up on a tree which stood there, she took that stick which she had picked up.
pê-kwâskohtici , kita-wîh-kisisin ! itwêw êsah . “When he comes leaping, let him impale himself!” she said.
tâpwê awa êh-kwâskohtit , kisisin awa mac-âyîsiyiniw kâ-nâh-nipahât ôhih oskinîkiskwêwah . And truly, as he jumped, he impaled himself, that evil man who used to kill the young women.
êkosi nipahêw awa pîhkahtêwâhtik ; nipahêw ôhih mac-âyîsiyiniwah . So Burnt-Stick killed him; she killed that evil man.
itohtêw ostêsah aspin itêh kâ-kiw-ohtaskatât . She went to where she had left her brothers when she departed.

hawîna kîh-wâpamêw , êh-mâtoyit , wiyah êh-mawihkâtikot , êh-at-is-itwêcik ,
kisîminaw okih-kitamôkoh wîhtikôwa ! êh-itwêyit , mêkwâc ostêsah kâ-pêhtawât . What did she see, they were weeping, mourning for her, and all the while saying, “Our little sister was eaten by the Windigo!” Thus spoke her brothers as she listened to them.
êkoyikohk pôni-mâtok , nistêsitik ! nitakohtân ! itwêw êsah . “Enough; cease weeping, brothers! I have come!” she said.
mistahi miywêyihtamok ôki oskinîkiwak . Those young men were very glad.
mitâtaht iskwêwah kakêkinêw êh-pimâcihât , êw-otinamowât ôhih iskwêwah . She had picked out ten of the women she had restored to life, and taken them for her brothers.
êkwah mistahi miywêyihtamok ôki nâpêwak , êh-wîwicik . Then those men were very glad to have wives.

kîtahtawê nanâtohk pîsk ,
namoya tâpwêh niya ayîsiyiniw , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiskwêw ; Then at one time, “I am not really a human being,” said the young woman; LB on {nanâtohk pîsk}: These two words have no place here. Perhaps the informant was going to say {nanâtohk pisiskiwah}: “various animals.”

seg.gloss: “And now my father wants me.
So I shall turn into a deer.
I have completed my benefaction to all of you, in giving you young women.”
